issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The earner of this badge will understand about ways to prepare for their interview, best practices for the interview process, and how to follow up after their interview. Answer the short 7-question quiz below to test the depth of your understanding on the subject matter presented and to earn your badge. Upload your 7 answers using this hyperlink.
1) Which of these is a sign of active listening? a) thinking of your own response to the interviewer b) nodding in agreement c) looking at your paper d) leaning away from the interviewer

2) Which of these best describes how to dress for success a) always wear the most formal suit possible b) always wear clothes that best express your individual personality c) always wear expensive, new clothes to show your commitment to the job d) always wear neat, well-fitting professional clothes that fit the company's environment
3) Which of these is the best source to find information about a company from people who have previously worked there?  a) Glassdoor b) The news c) Facebook d) Twitter

4) Which of these is the best way to follow up after an interview? a) Send a card through the mail the week after your interview b) Call within 48 hours and check the status of the job and show you care c) Within 24 hours write an email thank you note expressing your gratitude and interest d) Avoid following up. It will make you look desperate.

5) Which of these best describes a behavioral interview a) An interview in which you are asked to perform work behaviors b) An interview in which you are tested for your skills c) An interview in which they ask you psychological questions d) An interview in which they ask about how you would behave in a work-related scenario
6) Write a List response to this question: What do you think makes you a strong member of a team?
7) Write a story response to this question: Describe a time that you had to deliver bad news to a supervisor.

badge_template_activities.title: The learner will conduct an introspective self-assessment to identify their personal skills, experiences, and interests; explore careers and investigate what success looks like in careers they are interested in; and develop a tailored personal brand to communicate to future colleagues, employers, and other professional networks. To receive your badge you will need to complete four assignments (outlined below) and  will receive feedback from a Career Builder Mentor.

Assignment 1 - Introspective self-assessment - Display your identified keywords, skills, and experiences. Could be a photo of a wall full of sticky notes, a snapshot of a notebook, or a classic spreadsheet. Be creative!  Your introspective self-assessment your name, your original ideas plus your newly inspired ideas identified after completing your inspirational exercises with Job Ads and LinkedIn Profiles. These should be clearly marked as original and inspired.
Assignment 2 - Aspirational Exercise (Job Ads) - Save PDFs of 3 job ads you discovered that you were excited about and could see yourself in (now or in the future).

Assignment 3 – Inspirational Figures (LinkedIn Profiles)  - Make a list of LinkedIn Profiles (9 total) that inspired you based on the 3 Job Ad Titles you selected previously (3 each). Please also include a list of the 5 or more tips that you've implemented.
Assignment 4 – Final Project - Download a PDF of your new and improved LinkedIn Profile (click “Print” and “Save As” PDF).
When you are ready to submit your completed Assignments 1 - 4, use this hyperlink to upload and submit all four assignments.

aed1d5e6-864e-421c-b65a-d95d6d61a71f.description: Participants will examine how racial bias and racism have been constructed in the United States. As a part of our analysis, we will investigate socialization processes that contribute to racial bias, as well as negative outcomes produced by biases. We will also explore action steps each of us can take to combat racial bias and racism. Click on the "Learn More" link to watch this prerecorded session.
aed1d5e6-864e-421c-b65a-d95d6d61a71f.name: EQUITY & INCLUSIVITY: Deconstructing Racial Bias and Racism

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: Personal reflection is necessary for us to identify how we have been socialized to think about issues related to race and racism. In order to earn this badge, participants are required to reflect on three questions and submit written responses to  alvin.curette@utsa.edu

Q1: In reference to the Cycle of Socialization, discuss at least 3 specific points along the cycle that have influenced how you view people who are racially different from and similar to you Q2: What are 3 action steps you can take to combat racial bias and racism? Your responses can address short and/or long-term plans Q3: Why is it important that each of us stands against racial bias and racism? If we choose not to oppose bias and racism, what are some individual and societal ramifications?

9b82a8a3-621d-46cb-a6d1-1d6d77b1075b.description: We tend to "stay in our lanes" because it's comfortable. badge_template_activities.title: Attended a Social Justice Event (such as a Rally, City Hall meeting, Social Justice Bookclub), participated in a Service-Learning Project (such as MLK Day of Service, Food Bank, Boys and Girls Club), and attended a Spiritual place they typically don't attend (a church, mosque, temple, Wiccan ceremony). Or wrote an essay based on  conversations with one Social Justice Leader, one Service-Learning Leader, and one Spiritual Leader. Or see below for prompts for other ideas you might consider.
Proposals for initiatives/projects that can help begin to fix/improve upon systemic issues
Taking a seat at the table—being a student voice/representative on behalf of an organization at university meetings where decisions that impact the student body are being made

Help continue the conversation regarding anti-racism/inclusive excellence/DEI! Teach a workshop! Develop lesson plans that factor these things in! Host your own discussions with your community (on-campus or in your neighborhood)!
Work with community organizations/partners on projects that will tackle systemic issues (for example, getting rid of barriers to voting, addressing food insecurity, etc.)
Compiling resources that will help marginalized/disenfranchised groups (for example, a multilingual booklet with community resources/services for newly arrived refugees)
Fostering inclusivity and belonging on-campus (for example, working on increasing mental health awareness/access to mental healthcare for fellow students, etc.)
Other ideas you might have! Email To: ammi.bui@utsa.edu and CC: tracey.baas@utsa.edu and we can talk about it!

a35d6e8b-1503-4cfd-a817-c2d131f2b0a6.description: The earner has attended a session in the field to complete the Natural Resources Conservation Service Stream Visual Assessment Protocol; calculated the appropriate metrics and presented the data in a form that meets professional standards. To join field workshops, contact julian.chavez@utsa.edu for more information and calendar events.
a35d6e8b-1503-4cfd-a817-c2d131f2b0a6.name: FIELD TECHNIQUES: Aquatic Sampling

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The Learner must be one of the following:  (1) A current undergraduate student pursuing a degree in Environmental Science at UTSA with 60 hours or more, (2) A current graduate student in Environmental Science at UTSA A previous student with an undergraduate, or (3) graduate degree in Environmental Science from UTSA. The learner must also fill out a waiver to work in the field.
The learner will review the document Stream Visual Assessment Protocol Version 2 sponsored by the Natural Resource Conservation Service.
The learner will complete a Lesson and Exam in Google Classroom and score a grade of 80 or above.
The learner will participate in a field workshop to complete a stream visual assessment and will need to attend the entire workshop.
Assignment 1 - The learner will describe the stream and write a report based on the analyses. The learner will present this information in a form acceptable by the profession.
When ready to submit the completed assignment, use this link to upload one PDF. Be sure to include your name and email in the document so that your badge can be issued.

b52dd4a8-b7fc-46ef-a84e-b562fa94d6d2.description: The earner has attended a session in the field to estimate small animal populations using the Sherman live traps; calculate the appropriate metrics and presented the data in a form that clearly describes the small mammal population and meets professional standards. To join field workshops, contact julian.chavez@utsa.edu for more information and calendar events.
b52dd4a8-b7fc-46ef-a84e-b562fa94d6d2.name: FIELD TECHNIQUES: Estimation of Animal Populations

badge_template_activities.title: The Learner must be one of the following:  (1) A current undergraduate student pursuing a degree in Environmental Science at UTSA with 60 hours or more, (2)  A current graduate student in Environmental Science at UTSA, or (3) A previous student with an undergraduate or graduate degree in Environmental Science from UTSA. The learner must also fill out a waiver to work in the field.
The learner will review the document NEON Data Collection for Small Mammals sponsored by the National Science Foundation.
The learner will complete a Lesson and Exam in Google Classroom and score a grade of 80 or above.
The learner will participate in a field workshop to collect data using Sherman traps and must attend the entire workshop.
Assignment - The learner will estimate the density and diversity of small mammals in the sampled area. The learner will present this information in a form acceptable by the profession.
When ready to submit the completed assignment, use this link to upload one PDF. Be sure to include your name and email in the document so that your badge can be issued.

badge_template_activities.title: The Learner must be one of the following:  (1) A current undergraduate student pursuing a degree in Environmental Science at UTSA with 60 hours or more, (2) A current graduate student in Environmental Science at UTSA, or (3) A previous student with an undergraduate or graduate degree in Environmental Science from UTSA. The learner must also fill out a waiver to work in the field.
The learner will review the document NEON Data Collection for Terrestrial Plants sponsored by the National Science Foundation.
The learner will complete a Lesson and Exam in Google Classroom and score a grade of 80 or above.

The learner will participate in a field workshop to collect data using two plant estimation techniques, the quadrat method for woody plants and the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) method for sampling plant diversity of herbaceous data. To receive the badge, the entire workshop will need to be attended.

Assignment 1 - The learner will calculate the density, relative density, basal area, relative basal area, frequency, relative frequency, and relative importance for sampled woodland area. They will also calculate sample adequacy. Finally, the learner will present this information in a form acceptable by the profession.
Assignment 2 - The learner will calculate the percent cover and diversity of herbaceous species and present the data in a form acceptable by the procession.
When ready to submit completed assignments, use this link to upload one PDF and submit the two assignments. Be sure to include your name and email in the document so that your badge can be issued.

92c1ab25-5e96-4bf1-88f3-7a980acea200.description: The earner has attended a session in the field to participate in a workshop to collect soil cores; calculate the appropriate metrics and presented the data in a form that clearly describes soil characteristics and meets professional standards. To join field workshops, contact julian.chavez@utsa.edu for more information and calendar events.
92c1ab25-5e96-4bf1-88f3-7a980acea200.name: FIELD TECHNIQUES: Soil Sampling

The learner must also fill out a waiver to work in the field.

The learner will describe the soil physical characteristics, interpret characteristics from the Web Soil Survey, and write a soil survey report based on the analyses. The learner will present this information in a form acceptable by the profession.
When ready to submit the completed assignment, use this link to upload one PDF. Be sure to include your name and email in the document so that your badge can be issued.

1303a6fa-ff2d-4691-ad2d-3f7b14b9e412.description: During this module, students will be exposed to the fundamental concepts of graph theory in a manner that demonstrates its relevance to public policy topics. Specifically, they will be exposed to the problem of interdependence in policymaking and be given basic tools to begin to quantify those relationships.
1303a6fa-ff2d-4691-ad2d-3f7b14b9e412.name: GenAI: Data Visualization and Graphs

badge_template_activities.title: Learning Objectives: 1) Define both undirected and directed graphs 2) Document relationships in an adjacency matrix 3) Describe to the class an applied example of a graph structure (e.g trade relationships)

To earn your badge, you will need to complete the DS 1001 (Data Science for All) course modules. If you have questions or are interested in additional information, please email rebecca.schroeder@utsa.edu

fd930821-aa89-4fa7-8f38-47d7c06622a3.description: In this module, students will develop essential exploratory data analysis skills that are highly sought after across industries. They will gain an understanding of how business data can be used to track trends in a competitive business market and how visuals can be used to perceive the results of analysis. They practice data science concepts such as storing data, data analysis tools, data cleaning, summary statistics and visualizations.
fd930821-aa89-4fa7-8f38-47d7c06622a3.name: GenAI: Exploratory Data Analysis

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: Learning Objectives: 1) Describe methods of exploring common business data. 2) Use geographical data to create spatially related visual models. 3) Use Python’s Pandas library to work with and reference data in an efficient manner.

To earn your badge, you will need to complete the DS 1001 (Data Science for All) course modules. If you have questions or are interested in additional information, please email rebecca.schroeder@utsa.edu

b89e1917-d398-417d-bef2-05ad187234f2.description: Explore machine learning techniques using Python in a Jupyter Notebook to analyze the PIMA Indian Dataset. From this, the students will analyze visualizations and graphs derived from the analysis and determine if they can build a machine learning model to accurately predict whether or not the patients in the dataset have diabetes. The information generated will be analyzed to determine the relevant information for policymakers to make informed evidence-based public health policy decisions.
b89e1917-d398-417d-bef2-05ad187234f2.name: GenAI: Python Basics

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: After this lesson, students will be able to: 1) Describe how machine learning is used to identify diabetes risk factors. 2) Understand how the insights gained from research with large datasets have the potential to transform the way policymakers approach some of society's most important policy decisions. 3) Understand how robust evidence on previous policy outcomes and predictive modeling of future outcomes can guide policymakers to smarter policies with greater benefits at a lower cost.

After this lesson, students will be able to: 4) Identify major types of data bias that can occur in predictive analysis. 5) Discuss the importance of Evidence-Based Policymaking using administrative and “big” data. 6) Understand moderately advanced statistical inference. 7) Identify ML techniques that can assist in public policy decision-making.

Anticipated Outcomes: 1) Describe methods of exploratory data analysis used in research. 2) Analyze hypotheses for data related to risk for diabetes. 3) Evaluate a predictive model to inform decision-making for evidence-based assessment. 4) Correlate the data generated by the exploratory data analysis to identify a target for a public health campaign to prevent diabetes. 5) Use behavior-centered design principles to generate a public service announcement to support the diabetes health campaign

To earn your badge, you will need to complete the DS 1001 (Data Science for All) course modules. If you have questions or are interested in additional information, please email rebecca.schroeder@utsa.edu.

cc8b530f-fe5e-44b2-942b-ce850ac9b9c0.description: During this module, students will learn how to visualize and interpret a wordcloud and compare multiple wordclouds. They will also gain an understanding of sentiment analysis and brand monitoring on social media. The anticipated outcomes include a development of appreciation for marketing research, an understanding of customer complaints management, an interest in social media sentiment analysis, and an interest in R programming.
cc8b530f-fe5e-44b2-942b-ce850ac9b9c0.name: GenAI: Sentiment Analysis

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: After this lesson, students will be able to: 1) Visualize and interpret a wordcloud 2) Compare multiple wordclouds 3) Perform sentiment analysis 4) Understand brand monitoring of social media

Anticipated Outcomes: 1) Student will develop appreciation for marketing research 2) Students will develop understanding of customer complaints management 3) Students will develop an interest in social media sentiment analysis 4) Student will develop an interest in R programming

To earn your badge, you will need to complete the DS 1001 (Data Science for All) course modules. If you have questions or are interested in additional information, please email rebecca.schroeder@utsa.edu

595f0331-b34d-490c-9a47-16532abc0b38.description: During this module, students will have a comprehensive introduction to analyzing data from multiple tables. They will learn how to aggregate data from various sources and formulate coherent and insightful queries in a database. Familiarity with techniques used by data scientists daily will be gained, as well as a core understanding of working with SQL databases and how other languages can be used to make SQL queries.
595f0331-b34d-490c-9a47-16532abc0b38.name: GenAI: SQL and Databases

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: Learning Objectives: 1) Students will have an introduction to the concept of analyzing data culled from several tables of data. 2) Students will begin to understand the methods of aggregating data from several sources, as well as how to form coherent, insightful queries from a database. 3) Students will be familiar with techniques that data scientists use on a daily basis to perform data analysis in databases.

To earn your badge, you will need to complete the DS 1001 (Data Science for All) course modules. If you have questions or are interested in additional information, please email rebecca.schroeder@utsa.edu.

Ambassadors support and encourage the professional development of their peers in roles that have teaching responsibilities as representatives of The Graduate School and Academic Innovation; to include advancing academic excellence in graduate education and training; championing innovative and transformational practices to enhance the academic experience of students and faculty.

df1f561f-b730-4dbb-a548-638de727af35.description: The session introduces how collaborations have become more common in order to solve scientific grand challenges. To assure successful collaborations, researchers need to be particularly adept at dealing with increasingly complex roles and relationships; common, but not necessarily identical, interests and timelines; data sharing arrangements; management requirements; cultural differences; and intellectual property agreements. Online seminar through "Additional Details" coming soon.
df1f561f-b730-4dbb-a548-638de727af35.name: RCR: Collaborations in Academic and Industrial Settings

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The learner will be able to discuss common problems and possible solutions that arise during collaborative research, what crucial conversations need to occur during the initiation of a collaborative project, and what steps should be taken when a collaborative project comes to an end or is dissolved.
Homework TBD

d44bd12c-65af-4b70-8e74-8efaffb09f8f.description: The session discusses the many responsibilities scientists have to society, not just to their academic environments. This session will review the shared values, expectations, and responsibilities for scientists in conducting research, disseminating information to the public, and guiding scientific societies and scientific discourse. All these examples underscore the need for scientists to view their potential impact more broadly on society and not just on scientific contribution alone.
d44bd12c-65af-4b70-8e74-8efaffb09f8f.name: RCR: Conducting Research Responsibly

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The learner will become comfortable with discussing moral and ethical obligations that accompany scientific research and how scientists can be expected, at many levels, to benefit society and avoid causing harm. The learner can select to use concepts from their own research for discussion or can select to use prevalent current or historic news stories, such as embryonic stem cell research, use of individual and population genomic information, and DNA editing.
Homework TBD

89e5b75d-e3ec-49d6-9f40-2dd7026a4bd8.description: The session addresses conflicts of interest at the individual,university, and industry levels. A conflict of interest exists when two or more competing interests relate to an activity by an individual or an institution/company. The conflict lies in the situation, not in any behavior or lack of behavior of the individual. In research, these potential conflicts are not problematic in their existence but must be transparent and appropriately reported.
89e5b75d-e3ec-49d6-9f40-2dd7026a4bd8.name: RCR: Conflicts of Interest

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The learner will be able to identify conflicts of interest in research and will understand what information should be reported and to whom. Learners will create plans for problem solving in the context of scientific collaboration or entrepreneurship.
Homework TBD

fe5f9f50-6923-499b-86cc-59dfc6caadb9.description: The session covers accepted practices and procedures for acquiring, storing, organizing, documenting, analyzing, sharing and maintaining data. Importantly, the session will introduce how to write a data management plan, comply with sponsor and journal requirements for data sharing, and organize projects for reproducibility. Online seminar through "Additional Details" coming soon.
fe5f9f50-6923-499b-86cc-59dfc6caadb9.name: RCR: Data Management

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The learner will be able to write a data management plan for a research project that addresses multiple stages: data collection and classification, data organization and documentation, secure data storage, and data sharing, de-identification, and preservation. UTSA resources to meet these requirements will be shared.
Homework TBD

4a5a5b79-1575-476d-b5c4-9ec6fe864f3a.description: The session addresses fundamental ethical principles and required procedures in laboratory animal care and use. Learners will understand management responsibilities in animal research, institutional animal care and use committees, and appropriate care and treatment of animals. View the online seminar by following the link through "Additional Details."
4a5a5b79-1575-476d-b5c4-9ec6fe864f3a.name: RCR: Ethical Treatment of Animals in Research

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The learner will be able to discuss the importance of good animal welfare practices in research, understand regulations governing ethical use of animals in research and provide relevant resources on these guidelines.
Homework TBD

8ef4dcf0-5c95-4d5f-bf2d-601b420c3449.description: The session addresses complex issues pertaining to research and human subjects’ protections, including privacy, confidentiality, and protection of human data and biological materials. The development of U.S federal policies and practices are discussed from a sociohistorical perspective and linked to contemporary issues, such as the inclusion of vulnerable populations and the implication for ethical treatment of individuals and their personal information.
8ef4dcf0-5c95-4d5f-bf2d-601b420c3449.name: RCR: Ethical Treatment of Humans in Research

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The learner has reflected on the fundamental principles of research with humans and a variety of ethical considerations that arise in developing, conducting, monitoring, and reporting research, including the use of living human subjects, personally identifiable information, and human biological materials.
Homework TBD

5bcc0e3f-3ffd-4139-b3db-61a609c7c1f5.description: The session will highlight the unique opportunity in academia to both give and receive mentorship, emphasizing research team and lab dynamics. Skill-building activities around negotiation, mediation, and decision-making will be included, coupled with examples of the role of mentorship in scientific achievement and career direction. View the online seminar by following the link through "Additional Details."
5bcc0e3f-3ffd-4139-b3db-61a609c7c1f5.name: RCR: Mentoring in Research

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The learner will be able to identify power structures and hierarchical relationships within science and related mentoring relationships. They have also practiced skills that optimize the giving and receiving of mentorship within the UTSA scientific community and their extended network.
Homework TBD

a690eac0-408a-4571-b376-149129535c9e.description: This session will explain the role of the Research Integrity Officer at research universities and organizations, including administering federal requirements, ensuring understanding of policies and procedures, and serving as a resource to the research community. Specifically, this session will provide an overview of UTSA’s organization of research integrity and compliance oversight. Online seminar through "Additional Details" coming soon.
a690eac0-408a-4571-b376-149129535c9e.name: RCR: Relationship with the Research Integrity Officer

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: Learners will know how their Research Integrity Officer can meet their needs at UTSA and understand the procedures required to meet federal statutes and regulations, reporting mechanisms, and coordination across organizational units.
Homework TBD

88fa643e-7880-4b55-93d9-423161c4e6e0.description: The session addresses societal implications of scientific misconduct and unethical practices. Discussions within the seminar also address the prevalence of misconduct in science, reporting and management procedures, and possible ways to prevent its occurrence. Case studies will be provided. Online seminar through "Additional Details" coming soon.
88fa643e-7880-4b55-93d9-423161c4e6e0.name: RCR: Research Misconduct

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The learner will understand the significance of scientific misconduct and unethical behavior. They will be familiar with responsibilities of scientists to report possible research misconduct and protections for those who report. They will also be familiar with efforts within the scientific community (institutions, funding agencies, scientific journals, etc.) to address suboptimal research practices that may reduce the reliability of research results and impede scientific progress.
Homework TBD

00739345-ea7d-4a7f-91d3-5fbb44d7c9e3.description: The session will examine the responsibilities of authors in scientific publication and discuss procedures for assigning credit and authorship. It will also introduce potential pitfalls such as misunderstandings around contributions and the pressure to publish. The session will also explain peer reviewer responsibilities and their importance to the scientific community. Online seminar through "Additional Details" coming soon.
00739345-ea7d-4a7f-91d3-5fbb44d7c9e3.name: RCR: Responsible Authorship and Peer Review

issuer.summary: issued by University of Texas at San Antonio

entity.name: University of Texas at San Antonio

badge_template_activities.title: The learner will understand the responsibilities and ethical considerations of publishing for scientific and nonscientific audiences and will be familiar with how the peer review process works, including the roles of a reviewer and editor.
Homework TBD

ec41a405-b461-4246-8870-00a0c5b8b9c1.description: The Responsible Conduct of Research Collection introduces newly funded researchers to ten fundamental principles of conducting research ethically. Graduate students, postdocs, staff and faculty can earn the badges in the collection at any time but graduate students, postdocs and staff are required to complete the collection if receiving funding from NIH or NSF.
ec41a405-b461-4246-8870-00a0c5b8b9c1.name: RCR: RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT OF RESEARCH COLLECTION
